header.title: Sexist coverage steals the show at 2016 Olympics
header.subtitle: NA
header.postText: Liz Plank examines the double standards and sexism that pervade media coverage of the Olympics. Subscribe to our channel! http://goo.gl/0bsAjO. Vox.com is a news website that helps you cut through the noise and understand what's really driving the events in the headlines. Check out http://www.vox.com to get up to speed on everything from Kurdistan to the Kim Kardashian app.  Check out our full video catalog: http://goo.gl/IZONyE. Follow Vox on Twitter: http://goo.gl/XFrZ5H. Or on Facebook: http://goo.gl/U2g06o

I like most of Vox's content, even that which deals with gender issues, but this video really doesn't seem to fit in to the overall theme of Vox's channel. This smug, sarcastic commentary contrasts greatly with the usual even-headed, well-written/researched voiceovers that I'm used to. In addition, there were a few points that I didn't agree with at all. For example, the commentators only mentioned Hosszu's husband because he is also her coach, who is usually someone that is quite integral to an athlete's achievement. Also, when the remark about the gymnasts being in a mall was made, it was made in reference to how comfortable they looked, and how much fun they seemed to be having. Sure, the comment lacked a little tact, but you can't say that it was part of some sexist war being waged by NBC. Both of these examples would have seemed a lot less offensive if some context was provided. I thought Vox videos were made to inform people about pressing issues or just interesting topics, but this video seems like it was made for the sole purpose of stirring up vitriol from the audience. I'm just disappointed.

Vox - sexism was an issue in this Olympics, but Liz Plank's presentation is horrible, and the writing for this episode was terrible too. First off, you tried to make it funny and it isn't funny because there are no jokes. Simply pointing out a thing that happened, and telling your audience "Look how ridiculous that is!" doesn't make a joke funny. It's about delivery, timing, and set up. You have a decent set-up. The premise being you're addressing sexism like it's an Olympic sport - but if the premise is good, you don't need to mention it explicitly. It would be implied. Saying the premise explicitly means you think your audience is stupid. Delivery is not good. Frankly, Liz is too animated. If you're presenting this as if you're a sports caster, then it would be funny if Liz actually tried to act like one with the "news anchor voice" and demeanor. Liz tries to make these bits funny by pointing out the ridiculousness of these sports reporter's sexist comments, but it comes across as high & mighty and condescending. Timing is an issue too. These bits come one right after the other. Give the audience time to think about the sports reporter's comments, and take the time to actually write some decent commentary about the interaction. You give the facts and then do a quick one sentence bit about it. Actually dedicate some writing time to each interaction so the audience can have time to mull it over and slow down the pace a bit like in the other videos you guys have where you address topics seriously. This is why people are saying the video is "unprofessional," but really it's because it just isn't funny. Sexist jokes can be funny, but this video just is not. Your serious videos are way better - stick with that because you guys are not comedians.

This video should have been done in Vox's usual style -- it's hard to make people understand sexism unless your tone and intent is educational. I'm glad you're addressing sexism in Olympic coverage. +Nemesis9250Gaming the crux of the problem lies in the power structure in the system. Sure, racial minorities can form groups expressing charged views that can be seen as hostile toward another, but by definition this isn't racism. Racism is a systemic issue - it's the fact that the socioeconomic and political systems that drive our country are in fact designed against people of color. When we've used the word "racist" so colloquially we conflate its meaning with other words like "prejudiced." of course minorities can be prejudiced against white people. But there's no such thing as RACISM against white people in the academic sense of the word (and yes, the distinction in vocabulary IS important for purposes of studying, discussing and addressing the problem) because the course of history in America and indeed in much of the world has placed white people in a position of power by the exploitation (historically or currently) of other races. This is why people say minorities cannot be "racist" against whites, women are never "sexist" against men. By their very definition those claims are logically unsound.

+Nemesis9250Gaming to add to my other comment, in a different hypothetical nation where whites constitute a minority and the de jure or de facto conditions of the economic, legal, political and social environment in that country systemically oppresses white people, then yes in that nation there is a racist system against whites and many acts of individuals, the government or other groups can be correctly labeled as racist if it falls into that framework of oppression. In America obviously that's not the case.

Now it is claimed that we always should use both version if we speak of the profession more generally to be more inclusive while people used to default to the masculine version when speaking of the profession in a more general way but they also included women with this term e.g. when they were asked to name their favourite writers (masculine) they almost always also mentioned female authors even though they were not technically included by the masculine version of the word. I don't follow the other sports so I don't know the full context, but I feel like the tennis examples don't really work. Bouchard in particular is a pretty bad example. She went from being a top ten player to barely top 50 and has been focusing entirely on marketing. Despite being far better than many of her opponents, she barely won a match in 2015 and she hasn't been doing much better in 2016. Despite her lack of success, she has found time to appear in numerous adds and product placements. When it comes to marketing in women's tennis, being young and attractive is unfortunately more important than being successful (which is also why Sharapova made more money than Serena before she was banned for doping). As far as the comment about Murray being the first tennis player to win to Olympic gold medals, this seems to be more discrimination against doubles than against women's tennis. Doubles tennis is never treated with the same respect as singles regardless of gender. I think this is unfortunate since doubles players work just as hard as singles players but singles has more viewership and doubles is almost always forgotten. I assume the commentator would have clarified he was talking about mens tennis if either of the Williams sisters had a second singles medal. I'm not denying that there is sexism in Olympics coverage, and the other examples given do seem sexist to me (although I don't know the full context), but I feel like the two tennis examples don't show any obviou s sexism and they don't beling in this video.

Because if you take things out of context they look far worse than they actually are. If you or any one else believes that women are actually discriminated against in the Western world, then you have been manipulated. If feminists actually wanted to be helpful they would be trying to help women in places like the Middle East and Africa where women are treated like objects.

@Fricken Cool And you are a woman in the Western world, or indeed the ambassador of all women in the western world? The mere fact that you think you can judge how women feel, not only that - but ALL women - regardless on what evidence you're basing this on (for indeed no such evidence could possibly exist) speaks of a problem that is in a way at least related to the overall problem of discrimination against women, whether it be here in the West, or in other places. Comparing different kinds and degrees of discrimination does not help. Neither does denying that there is a problem. Don't get me wrong, friend, I also cringe and wince at ultra feminists, or the so called femi-nazis, who hyperbolize otherwise inadequate problems; but, to suggest that there is NO discrimination, even if it is a milder form of discrimination, left in the West, to me is absolutely absurd. There has been progress, true, but nobody in their right mind would expect a mere century to heal all previous indiscretions (unless, of course, you don't think there were any indiscretions to begin with?) My stance, as a male, white (ish), lower middle class person is merely this: I listen to people when they talk about their problems - I don't dismiss them. I do dismiss the fringe arguments who are doing more damage to their cause as opposed to helping it (i.e. ultra feminists) but I listen to those in the middle who don't act all victimised and like society owes them anything, in fact they just state what THEY PERCEIVE the problem to be. "They perceive" being key here, since if something affects their perception to such an extent as to awaken any sort of mutually-felt discomfort in a pattern-like manner then maybe, just maybe, there is a problem there? Maybe not a problem as "big" as the problems women have in other parts of the world, but comparing the two is like saying: "Those holocaust survivors hav e nothing to moan about, people have been, and continue to die in much bigger numbers in total, so it's not a big deal" - yes it is, and yes it was, regardless of all other pain and suffering there may have, or indeed may still exist, the two are not mutually exclusive. Do you get my point? Sorry if I offended, was not my intention to do so, in fact I think your argument is well structured and based on truth. I just don't see how that excludes problems of women here.

+likeastarbaby Many sexist jokes against women are insider jokes between people from several large online communities. E.g. "Go back to the kitchen and make me a sandwich" doesn't mean "You're just a woman, you belong in the kitchen". I understand why it would seem like that, I understand why outsiders cannot see how it could be funny, and I'm sure some people writing it actually means it. But that describes all insider jokes and I'm also sure most people writing it doesn't feel that way. Also, generally the feeling of being disconnected from people you write to releases restraints on people. They can tell the world their opinion, even if they'd never tell it to your face. The way I see it: - research on popular opinions based on internet comments will over represent more aggressive opinions. - research on popular opinions based on real life surveys will over represent more look-at-me-I'm-such-a-good-person opinions. This may or may not actually be true. Just my own general prejudice towards either.

commentThread.commentText: This was really obnoxious.

A lot of this was taken far out of context. Let's review some of them: 1. The commentator said the teenage girls on the USA gymnastics team may as well have been standing in a mall because he was commenting on how calm they were and didn't seem to be bothered by the magnitude of the event. 2. With the tennis player who won two gold singles medals, it was implied that it was for men's. A woman doing the same is irrelevant. TV coverage does the same thing the other way around too to make people more interested; just last night, after the women's 400m hurdles, the commentators were saying how the American who won was the first American to win gold in the 400m hurdles - an American man had already got gold in the 400m hurdles, but that was irrelevant because it was a different event. 3. Phelps winning the silver was the headline because everyone wants to hear about Phelps. Ledecky (did I spell her name right?) is a great swimmer and had an impressive swim, but Phelps has so much fame

replies.commentText: I think a Michael Phelps who's losing (that's what we call second place here in America) is less interesting than a Ledecky who is not a random Olympian that nobody has heard of before: She is a five-time Olympic gold medalist, and nine-time world champion. She is the current world-record holder in the women's 400-, 800-, and 1,500-meter freestyle (long course). She also holds the fastest times in the 500-, 800-, 1000-, and 1,650-yard freestyle events. In her international debut at the 2012 London Olympic Games as a 15-year-old upstart, Ledecky unexpectedly won the gold medal in the women's 800-meter freestyle in the second fastest performance ever. In total, she has won 20 medals, 19 golds and one silver, in major international competitions, spanning the Summer Olympics, the World Championships, and the Pan Pacific Championships. During her career, she has broken thirteen world records. Ledecky's seven individual gold medals at the World Aquatics Championships is a record in women's swimming. Her combined individual titles at the Olympics and World Aquatics Championships are a record for female swimmers.  Ledecky's success has earned her Swimming World's World Swimmer of the Year and the American Swimmer of the Year awards in 2013, 2014 and 2015, as well as the FINA Swimmer of the Year Award in 2013. Ledecky was also named the international female Champion of Champions by L'Équipe in 2014. She was named USOC SportsWoman of the Year: 2012–13. In 2016, Ledecky was the youngest person on Time magazine's Time 100 list. I could go on, but the point is that she is to women's swimming what Phelps is to men's and is worth similar note.

commentThread.commentText: I do agree with the overall sentiment of this video, but a few of the examples are reaching just a bit. The Phelps/Ledecky headlines, for example: If we replace Michael Phelps finishing 2nd in his discipline with say, Serena Williams finishing second in hers (I know she didn't, but just for the sake of argument), Ledecky is still the secondary headline in my view. Why? Because Williams is an international sports icon. Putting her on the front page of your paper is simply going to sell more copies than putting Ledecky on the front, no matter what record(s) she set. Its the same thing with Phelps. He's been a household name for YEARS, so people want to know how he did. It has nothing to do with him being a man, and everything to do with him being a living legend.

This made me severely cringe. First time I unsubbed from a channel because of one video.

Katinka Hosszu's husband is also her COACH, so yes a substantial part of her success could be attributed to him just as it can be for any top tier athlete. Who do they dump a cooler on when an NFL team wins the Superbowl? It isn't the Tight End. Nobody doubts that Hosszu is an outstanding athlete and she has a world record to prove it, but giving her husband credit for part of that success isn't sexism when he deserves it. Also, Phelps getting top billing for silver in that article probably has a lot more to do with his name recognition tha n sexism. A lot more people on the street are going to recognize Phelps than Ledecky, so if you're trying to sell newspapers, you put his name at the top. I guess Occam'z razor doesn't apply when you're trying to push an agenda. This video is clearly pushing an agenda and honestly it isn't even doing it that well. The Olympics have been going for two weeks now and coverage has been going on for longer than that. You cherry picked a couple of articles (not even articles really, mostly clips and headlines taken out of context) and extrapolated that into proof of systemic and widespre ad sexism in sports journalism. I don't buy it.

Not sexist. 1:11 He's not only her husband, but also her coach. A victory for an athlete is surely also an achievement for the coach. The commentator is only saying the man successfully coached his wife to become a better swimmer than she was. Not sexist. 1:40 It's a tweet. This is the Chicago Tribune trying to put as many information as possible in 140 characters, resulting in poor headlining. I might be persuaded into thinking this was sexist if the name of the Bears' lineman was put in the tweet. Alas, this is not the case. 1:55 Okay, he should have said the first man.
